content:
When using VS Code with jshint installed I would get the following error displayed whenever I opened a JavaScript project: I want jshint to be available globally … I want it to be available in all JavaScript projects. So I went to the command line and dutifully entered npm install -g jshint thinking that it would fix the problem. It did not! ‚òπÔ∏è
A bit of searching on the net dredged up this very problem on StackOverflow. This answer was particularly helpful! Thanks Abdollah! üëç üôÇ
What I took from the SO issue was that the solution requires two steps:
Issue npm install -g jshint (done ‚úÖ üòÑ) and then, Configure the jshint node path in the VS Code preferences (not yet ‚ùé üôÅ). So, what is the global node path on my device?
To find that out, one must use the npm root -g command. Use that command if you are using npm AND you specifically want to find the global root, otherwise use npm root to to find the local node path. üëç
Here is a short asciinema asciicast of the process:
As I said, I want the location of the global node path and for me that is /usr/local/lib/node_modules. This location is the location relevant to a Homebrew install. If you installed node via nvm, then the location on macos is more likely to be something like ~/.nvm/versions/node/v12.18.3/lib/node_modules.
Finally, open VS Code Settings, search for jshint node path in the Search settings field and then enter the global node path i.e. again, for me it’s /usr/local/lib/node_modules.
After setting the jshint node path you can check it by opening the Command Palette and typing show output.
The output window should show something like this:
1 [Info - 10:45:37 PM] jshint library loaded from /usr/local/lib/node_modules/jshint/src/jshint.js Et voil√†! üòÖ
Update 1:
I originally installed node via Homebrew but this is apparently not best practice since a package manager (brew) is installing another package manager (npm) so I have uninstalled the brewed version of node and reinstalled the most recent version (v12.18.3 at time of publishing) via nvm.
Find a description of the issue here.
Find the GitHub nvm repo here.
Update 2:
The “VS Code JSHint extension” setup documentation says that the extension will look in the jshint module in the current directory and in the global package location … maybe it’s just me, but the extension does not seem to look in the global location and I had to update the jshint node path with the correct path.
Find the JSHint extension repo here on GitHub.

content:
TL;DR
Add /* after the opening shortcode tags i.e., {{< and */ before the closing shortcode tags i.e. >}}
While creating the post Beautifulhugo Theme Extras - Shortcodes (Split), I had quite a bit of trouble finding the answer to the question of “how can I display a block code in my post?”.
The answer seemed obvious, use a code fence i.e. use triple backticks; OR indent the code block using 4 spaces; OR after adding a colon (:), surround the code by two blank lines, one at the top and one below the last line of code.
As it turned out, that was the wrong question! I, Robot anyone?
The right question was “what is the markdown escape sequence required to correctly display a hugo shortcode in my post i.e. without it being interpreted?”.
The answer eventually came to me via Desmond Lua at LuaSoftware.
Thanks Desmond! üòÖ

Another extra beautifulhugo theme shortcode is called split. This shortcode splits the page into two columns. The example shown in the doco in the beautifulhugo repo (at the time of writing) was a little confusing because the closing endcolumns tag was incorrect (missing an s). Got there in the end. üòÖ
It should look like this:
1 2 3 4 5 {{< columns >}} First column on the right side of the page {{< column >}} Second column on the left side of the page {{< endcolumns >}} Yes, the first tag is columns whereas the intermediate tag is column. And the closing tag is again a plural i.e. endcolumns.

content:
An extra beautifulhugo theme shortcode is called details (checking the code itself shows that it is based on the HTML <details> tag). This shortcode hides some content until the text set on the detail is clicked.
An example follows:
Click here to expand to show hidden content! This is the content you’d like to hide. üßò
The actual code used in this post for the previous example looks like this:
1 2 3 {{< details "Click here to expand to show the content!" >}} This is the content you'd like to hide. üßò {{< /details >}} I had trouble adding spacing to the content in the details shortcode above so I resorted to adding HTML <br> tags but that didn’t work either. Probably need to escape some HTML or something like that - not looking into that now though - maybe for another time.
Curiously also, I found that it is impossible (for me) to add extra whitespace after the details shortcode. I’ve tried adding 1 or more blank lines inside of <pre></pre> tags and I tried adding numerous <br> tags after the details shortcode but neither of these approaches worked. In fact when I add a <br> tag after the shortcode the line after is not displayed … not sure what is going on.
The learning continues! üèÉ
UPDATE: I am using the PaperMod theme now and so I needed to copy the shortcode code from that project for this original blog post to work … and it does (to a degree) …

content:
The beautifulhugo theme has support for Hugo’s Chroma (a general purpose syntax highlighter in pure Go) syntax highlighting.
Let me try that out! üöÄ
Add the following to the site config i.e.config.toml file:
1 2 pygmentsCodeFences = true pygmentsUseClasses = true Then from the command line, generate the desired new code style (in my case, monokai) by running:
1 hugo gen chromastyles --style=monokai > static/monkai.css Or if you want to add more structure to your static files, add the following to the site config i.e. config.toml file:
1 staticDir = ["static", "static/css"] And then re-generate the code style using the new folder path i.e. static/css :
1 hugo gen chromastyles --style=monokai > static/css/monkai.css
